data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An opening constructed in a wall, door, or roof that functions to admit light or air to an enclosure and is often framed and spanned with glass mounted to permit opening and closing.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A framework enclosing a pane of glass for such an opening; a sash.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A pane of glass or similar material enclosed in such a framework.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An opening or transparent part that resembles a window in function or appearance.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The transparent panel on a window envelope.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The area or space immediately behind a window, especially at the front of a shop.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A means of access or observation.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: St. Petersburg was Peter the Great's window onto the Baltic.

data.text: An interval of time during which an activity can or must take place.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a window of opportunity for a space mission; a window of vulnerability when the air force was subject to attack.
